title: Opening Line Freeze
situation: You matched with someone whose profile you really like, but your mind goes blank when you try to write the first message.
question: How do you start the conversation?

choices.label: “Hey, how are you?”
choices.outcome: They might respond, but it doesn’t help the conversation stand out or go anywhere specific.
choices.insight: Generic openers are safe but forgettable. They put all the work back onto the other person.

choices.label: “Your photo at the coast looks amazing. Is that your favorite place you’ve traveled to?”
choices.outcome: They feel seen and have an easy, enjoyable thing to talk about. The conversation starts with energy.
choices.insight: Pointing at a specific detail shows you’re genuinely paying attention and makes responding simple.

choices.label: “Rate my opening line 1–10: ‘I can’t decide if I’m more into your smile or your dog.’”
choices.outcome: Some people find it playful; others may see it as trying a bit too hard, depending on their style.
choices.insight: Playful self-awareness can work well, but it still needs to feel respectful and not overly rehearsed.

title: The Dry Reply
situation: You send a thoughtful message and get a one-word reply: “lol” or “nice”.
question: What do you do next?

choices.label: Reply with an equally short message to show you’re not trying too hard.
choices.outcome: The conversation slowly fades out. Neither of you gives it enough energy to grow.
choices.insight: Mirroring low effort can protect your pride but often kills potentially good connections.

choices.label: Send another open question connected to what you were talking about.
choices.outcome: Sometimes they open up more the second time; other times the energy stays flat and you learn they’re not that interested.
choices.insight: You can’t control their level of interest, but you can give the conversation one more clear chance before moving on.

choices.label: Confront them: “If you’re not interested, just say so instead of half-replying.”
choices.outcome: They may withdraw or get defensive. The conversation ends with tension instead of clarity.
choices.insight: Calling someone out harshly for low effort can feel justified but often shuts the door on any future warmth.

title: Too Many Messages
situation: You’re excited about someone and find yourself sending multiple long messages before they have time to respond.
question: How can you adjust?

choices.label: Keep messaging whenever you think of something—you want them to know you’re interested.
choices.outcome: They may feel overwhelmed and struggle to keep up or disengage entirely.
choices.insight: Interest is attractive; intensity can be draining. Space helps the other person participate too.

choices.label: Pause, wait for their reply, and channel your thoughts into a journal or friend chat instead.
choices.outcome: You still get to express your excitement without putting pressure on the other person.
choices.insight: Managing your own anxiety off the app can create a calmer, more equal-feeling conversation.

choices.label: Apologize for the long messages and say you’ll stop texting altogether.
choices.outcome: They may reassure you, but the sudden withdrawal can feel confusing.
choices.insight: Repairing over-texting doesn’t require disappearing; it just means adjusting to a more balanced pace.

title: Voice Note or Text?
situation: You’re about to respond to a deeper message about their past relationships.
question: What format do you use?

choices.label: A short text that acknowledges what they shared and gently asks a follow-up.
choices.outcome: You stay present without overstepping. They feel heard and can respond at their own pace.
choices.insight: Text can be intimate when it’s specific, grounded, and not rushed.

choices.label: A long, emotional voice note sharing your entire relationship history in response.
choices.outcome: It may feel like too much too soon for them, and hard to reply to fully.
choices.insight: Matched vulnerability works best when it’s paced, not dumped all at once.

choices.label: Ignore the deeper part and respond only to the lighter parts of their message.
choices.outcome: They may feel a bit unseen or regret opening up.
choices.insight: Avoiding depth can keep things comfortable but also limits the potential for genuine connection.
